Award.AwardTitle: Doctoral Dissertation Research: The Effects of College Degrees on Health Behaviors

Directorate.LongName: Direct For Social, Behav & Economic Scie

Division.LongName: Divn Of Social and Economic Sciences

Award.AbstractNarration:
SES-1435316
Fred Pampel
Elizabeth M. Lawrence
University of Colorado at Boulder

Among U.S. adults, college degree earners live much healthier lives than those with less education, but we know little about why. Further, recent trends show that health and social disparities across educational levels are widening. Determining how and why educational attainment influences health behaviors, such as smoking, exercising, maintenance of healthy weight status, and heavy drinking, can help us understand how inequality emerges in our society. Health behaviors are important because they signify social class and shape the health and longevity of individuals. This project will determine how the effects of college degrees differ across groups for multiple health behavior outcomes.

Three research questions characterize the study's objectives: (1) What are the average causal effects of college degrees on multiple indicators of health behaviors? (2) How do the effects of college degrees on the different health behavior outcomes differ across the likelihood of achieving the degree, a person?s race, or a person's gender? (3) What are the mechanisms for the college degree-health behavior relationship and are they different across groups? To answer these questions, this study draws on quantitative methods analyzing survey data from a recent, nationally representative sample. The National Longitudinal Study of Adolescent Health (Add Health) provides longitudinal data on education and health behaviors across adolescence and young adulthood for a cohort of individuals born 1977-1984.

The results will indicate who benefits most from college degrees, whether these degrees serve to moderate or strengthen existing social inequalities, and what accounts for the college degree-health behavior relationship overall and within different subgroups. By revealing the conditions of education's benefits for health behaviors, this project has the potential to promote the well-being of individuals nationwide. Tobacco use, poor diet and physical activity, and alcohol consumption are leading causes of death and improving these behaviors would enhance the health of U.S. adults. In drawing broad conclusions as to the source of educational advantages for health, this study will provide useful information to policymakers interested in reducing social inequality. For example, by distinguishing the populations that are most and least responsive to college educations, the project results can be used to identify targets for intervention.

POR.DRECONTENT:
Among U.S. adults, college degree earners live much healthier lives than those with less education, but we know little about why. Further, recent trends show that health and social disparities across educational levels are widening. Determining how and why educational attainment influences health behaviors, such as smoking, exercising, maintenance of healthy weight status, and heavy drinking, can help us understand how inequality emerges in our society. Health behaviors are important because they signify social class and shape the health and longevity of individuals.

This project examined in detail the relationship between college degrees and health behaviors to determine who benefits from college degrees, if some groups benefit more than others, and what types of resources account for the healthier behaviors among college graduates. We know little about why more educated individuals live more healthfully, and this study broke new empirical ground on this topic. This project used a recent, nationally representative data set that surveyed a cohort of individuals born 1977-1984 in adolescence and young adulthood.

Our team expected that college graduates would smoke less, exercise more, have greater rates of healthy weight status, eat fast food less often, and drink fewer sugar-sweetened beverages than those less educated, and this was indeed the case for the group of U.S. young adults examined. However, college graduates did not display a clear advantage for alcohol consumption. We also expected that individuals who go on to graduate from college would differ in adolescence, and that these differences would bring about some of the differences in young adult health behaviors. For example, individuals who have college educated parents would be more likely to graduate from college and abstain from smoking. The results indicated that college graduates are the kind of people who are healthier, but such differences do not completely explain the relationship between college degrees and health behaviors. The attainment of a college degree appears to not just signify certain characteristics, but also improve health behaviors.

The project hypothesized that some individuals would benefit from college degrees more than others. Prior research has shown that individuals of different socioeconomic or race/ethnic backgrounds have different experiences in college. Surprisingly, for the most part, degrees had similar effects across class background and race/ethnicity, gender, and immigrant status. The benefits of college degrees (and education) appear to be available to everyone, even if it is harder for some to achieve those degrees.

The study also tested whether the greater financial, cognitive, occupational, status, social, and psychological resources of college graduates account for the healthier behaviors of this group. Surprisingly, financial, social, cognitive, and psychological resources are not the main reasons why college graduates behave more healthfully. Occupational characteristics and subjective social status explained more of the relationship between college degrees and health behaviors. Overall, educational attainment has many effects and we are only beginning to understand how these diffuse effects improve well-being.

College degrees improve health behaviors for all college graduates, leaving those without degrees lagging behind. This study has implications for policymakers intending to reduce social inequality, improve population health behaviors, and reduce educational disparities in health behaviors.
